vulnerability_information:
##Description
Hello. I discovered Cross-Site scripting issue on the https://www.data.gov/local/ endpoint.
The issue can be site-wide, and exploitable in any place, where pagination exist.

##The Impact and Severity
I assigned the High severity, because unlike the last #263226 report (that XSS was exploitable in the Firefox only), this XSS works in all browsers (Chrome/IE/Firefox).
But, considering that this case requires user interaction (hovering the mouse to the Page 2), the severity can be lowered to the Medium, if you consider so.

##POC (Reflected XSS)
Use this link in the Mozilla Firefox, Chrome or IE
https://www.data.gov/local/?&q&zzz%27onmou%3Cseover=1&ale%3Crt(%27xsp%27%3C)%3C;1;%20//

and hover the mouse to the page 2.
{F217930}

##Suggested fix
Sanitize the URLs in the `<div class="pagination">` block.
title: Reflected XSS on the data.gov (WAF bypass+ Chrome XSS Auditor bypass+ works in all browsers)

summaries.content:
*Thanks to the 18F team for the great experience, fast fix, and the bounty!*

This case was weird. The XSS worked only with few `&` chars in certain places (identified by trial-and-error method), and input appeared to be correctly sanitized without it.
It bypassed Chrome XSS auditor, and due to stripping chars function in place (hi `FILTER_SANITIZE_STRING`) it also bypassed Kona WAF using stripped chars in the payload. It is a curious example, how two different defense mechanisms neutralize each other.
The discovered XSS issue was site-wide and affected 80+ endpoints.
summaries.content_html:
Thanks to the 18F team for the great experience, fast fix, and the bounty!

This case was weird. The XSS worked only with few & chars in certain places (identified by trial-and-error method), and input appeared to be correctly sanitized without it.
It bypassed Chrome XSS auditor, and due to stripping chars function in place (hi FILTER_SANITIZE_STRING) it also bypassed Kona WAF using stripped chars in the payload. It is a curious example, how two different defense mechanisms neutralize each other.
The discovered XSS issue was site-wide and affected 80+ endpoints.

activities.message:

https://www.data.gov/food/?&q&zzz%27onmou%3Cseover=1&ale%3Crt(%27xsp%27%3C)%3C;1;%20//
https://www.data.gov/consumer/?&q&zzz%27onmou%3Cseover=1&ale%3Crt(%27xsp%27%3C)%3C;1;%20//

etc.

activities.message:
Interesting to figure the root cause of this - because the initial payload even haven't double quotes, due to correct html encoding. But something breaks the event handler (i think that the first `'` becomes the `"`, but all next singlequotes reflected as is).

The unescaped reflection happens only in combination with `&`, what makes me think that it can be a WAF, some input filter, or parameters parsing fault.
Same payload without `&` will not work:
https://www.data.gov/local/?zzz%27onmou%3Cseover=1ale%3Crt(%27xsp%27%3C)%3C;1;%20//
{F218652}
but when we add few `&` (one will not be enough - without 3rd `&` there will be no reflection)
it will work:
https://www.data.gov/local/?&q&zzz%27onmou%3Cseover=1&ale%3Crt(%27xsp%27%3C)%3C;1;%20//
activities.markdown_message:
Interesting to figure the root cause of this - because the initial payload even haven't double quotes, due to correct html encoding. But something breaks the event handler (i think that the first ' becomes the ", but all next singlequotes reflected as is).

The unescaped reflection happens only in combination with &, what makes me think that it can be a WAF, some input filter, or parameters parsing fault.
Same payload without & will not work:
https://www.data.gov/local/?zzz%27onmou%3Cseover=1ale%3Crt(%27xsp%27%3C)%3C%3B1%3B%20//

but when we add few & (one will not be enough - without 3rd & there will be no reflection)
it will work:
https://www.data.gov/local/?&q&zzz%27onmou%3Cseover=1&ale%3Crt(%27xsp%27%3C)%3C%3B1%3B%20//

I figured out the root cause - the pagination links has href attribute data included in single quotes instead double quotes:

and thats why single quote in the payload can break the attribute.
Example: https://github.com/GSA/data.gov/blob/master/roots-nextdatagov/templates/content-all-apps-pagination.php, line 368:

Looks like

$query = filter_var($_GET['q'], FILTER_SANITIZE_STRING);

on line 44 does not sanitize string completely.

So changing the single quote to the double quotes when building href attribute (or escaping the single quote in the input) should fix the issue.

In overall i detected 80 endpoints (using Google Search), affected by this XSS (it can be more of them as any page with pagination is affected):
affected_endpoints.txt (F218912)

activities.message: My apologies, mentioned source file looks like only the particular case of the issue (it affects only https://www.data.gov/applications path) - so i didn't figure the root cause:)

Description

Hello. I discovered Cross-Site scripting issue on the https://www.data.gov/local/ endpoint.
The issue can be site-wide, and exploitable in any place, where pagination exist.

The Impact and Severity

I assigned the High severity, because unlike the last #263226 report (that XSS was exploitable in the Firefox only), this XSS works in all browsers (Chrome/IE/Firefox).
But, considering that this case requires user interaction (hovering the mouse to the Page 2), the severity can be lowered to the Medium, if you consider so.

POC (Reflected XSS)

Use this link in the Mozilla Firefox, Chrome or IE
https://www.data.gov/local/?&q&zzz%27onmou%3Cseover=1&ale%3Crt(%27xsp%27%3C)%3C%3B1%3B%20//

and hover the mouse to the page 2.

Suggested fix
